events.title: Birth and Baptism
events.summary: Orlando Gibbons was born into a musical family and is believed to have been baptized at St Martin's Church, Oxford, on Christmas Day 1583, although he spent most of his early life in Cambridge. His family's musical background influenced his upbringing significantly.
events.fun_version: Orlando Gibbons came into the world not with a cry, but an aria, thanks to his musical family! Born on Christmas Day 1583, he ditched the sleigh ride in favor of a more academic life in Cambridge, where he spent most of his early years. Can you blame him? With a musical background like his, who needs reindeer?

events.title: Joining the Choir of King's College
events.summary: At the age of 12, Gibbons became a member of Edward's Choir of King's College, Cambridge, marking the beginning of his musical career. He remained a regular member until the Michaelmas term of 1598.
events.fun_version: At the age of 12, Gibbons joined Edward's Choir at King's College, Cambridge, proving you can hit all the right notes before hitting puberty! He remained a regular until the Michaelmas term of 1598, when he gracefully bowed out, probably to seek fame and fortune or a solo!

events.title: Professional Musician at Chapel Royal
events.summary: Gibbons became a musician of the Chapel Royal by May 19, 1603. His first professional position came in the same year that saw the death of both his mother and brother.
events.fun_version: So, Gibbons joined the Chapel Royal as a musician on May 19, 1603, right around the time he decided to really hit those high notes! His first professional position marked the start of a noteworthy career, coinciding with the year he faced personal losses in his family.

events.title: Appointment as Gentleman of the Chapel Royal
events.summary: On March 21, 1605, Gibbons secured the prestigious position of Gentleman of the Chapel Royal, becoming the junior chapel organist after the death of Arthur Cook.
events.fun_version: On March 21, 1605, Gibbons secured the prestigious position of Gentleman of the Chapel Royal, which is like being the VIP of organ music! He became the junior chapel organist, probably trying to impress the big guys. It's an organ-ized mess!

events.title: Marriage to Elizabeth Patten
events.summary: Orlando Gibbons married Elizabeth Patten on February 17, 1606. Their marriage was facilitated by her father, who was well-acquainted with Gibbons.
events.fun_version: Orlando Gibbons married Elizabeth Patten on February 17, 1606, with a little help from her dad, who must have been well-acquainted with Gibbons, or maybe just excellent at matchmaking. You know it's serious when your father doubles as your wedding planner!

events.title: Publication of First Set of Madrigals and Motets
events.summary: In the 1610s, Gibbons published his 1612 First Set of Madrigals and Motets, which included compositions that became famous, such as The Silver Swan. This work was dedicated to his patron, Sir Christopher Hatton.
events.fun_version: In the 1610s, Gibbons was busy hitting the high notes with his 1612 First Set of Madrigals and Motets. You know, the songs that made 'The Silver Swan' the diva of the bird world! This fantastic work was dedicated to his number one fan, Sir Christopher Hatton.

events.title: Publication in Parthenia
events.summary: In 1613, Gibbons had six works published in the first printed collection of English keyboard music, Parthenia, which celebrated the marriage of Princess Elizabeth Stuart to Frederick V of the Palatinate.
events.fun_version: In 1613, Gibbons dropped six musical tracks! These musical gems were featured in 'Parthenia,' the first printed collection of English keyboard music. It wasn’t simply for music's sake but to celebrate the grand wedding of Princess Elizabeth Stuart to Frederick V of the Palatinate—because nothing says ‘I do’ like a good aria!

events.title: Joint Organist of the Royal Chapel
events.summary: By at least 1615, Gibbons was the joint organist of the Royal Chapel alongside Edmund Hooper, receiving two grants from King James I in the same year for his good and faithful service.
events.fun_version: By at least 1615, Gibbons was the joint organist of the Royal Chapel alongside Edmund Hooper, sharing the organ like two kids squabbling over the last cookie! The duo even managed to snag two grants from King James I for their good and faithful service.

events.title: Assault Incident
events.summary: In 1620, Gibbons was the victim of an assault by Henry Eveseed, a yeoman of the vestry. The complaint noted that Eveseed violently attacked Gibbons, throwing him down and tearing his band from his neck. This incident stands out as a bizarre event in Gibbons's otherwise normal life.
events.fun_version: In 1620, poor Gibbons found himself in quite the pickle when Henry Eveseed, who fancied himself a 'yeoman of the vestry', decided that a wrestling match was in order. Instead of a handshake, Gibbons received an unexpected flying tackle, which really takes the cake for bizarre incidents in his otherwise mundane life, especially since it wasn't just a friendly match!

events.title: Organist at Westminster Abbey
events.summary: In 1623, Gibbons succeeded John Parsons as the organist at Westminster Abbey, marking one of the most significant positions in his career.
events.fun_version: Back in 1623, Gibbons, in a rather monumental career move, took over as the organist at Westminster Abbey from John Parsons, an event so significant that even the church bells were jealous of his new gig!

events.title: Death
events.summary: Orlando Gibbons died in May 1625 in Canterbury, succumbing to an illness, likely a brain hemorrhage, while preparing for the arrival of Queen Henrietta Maria. He was buried in Canterbury Cathedral.
events.fun_version: Orlando Gibbons took his final bow in May 1625 in Canterbury while gearing up for Queen Henrietta Maria's royal visit! He succumbed to an illness, likely a brain hemorrhage, before he could welcome her properly. He was laid to rest in Canterbury Cathedral.

works.title: I Feign Not Friendship where I Hate
I Tremble Not at Noyse of Warre
